user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of process_param__shared:
```c
static enum PerfRepl_param_result
process_param__shared (const char *param_name)
{
  if (tool_params.single)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Parameter '%s' cannot be used together "
             "with '-I' or '--single'.\n", param_name);
    return PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR;
  }
  if (tool_params.unique)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Parameter '%s' cannot be used together "
             "with '-U' or '--unique'.\n", param_name);
    return PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR;
  }
  tool_params.shared = ! 0;
  return '-' == param_name[1] ?
         PERF_RPL_PARAM_FULL_STR :PERF_RPL_PARAM_ONE_CHAR;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I selected the two conditional blocks, the assignment to tool_params.shared, and the final ternary return because these are the executable statements where unreachable-code issues could arise depending on invariants elsewhere in the project (e.g. whether tool_params.single and tool_params.unique can ever both be true or whether param_name can have properties making branches impossible). No other fragments in this function need investigation for MISRA Rule 2.1: the function signature, braces and whitespace are structural, there is no code after a return (no dead tail code), and there are no other statements hidden in macros or additional lines. Note: I did not flag the param_name[1] dereference as an unreachable-code issue because Rule 2.1 concerns reachability; potential undefined behavior from a NULL or short string is a separate concern outside the scope of Rule 2.1 and so was not included.
